casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Appellee, v. Randy Lee McCLEAN, Appellant. No. 00-2973. United States Court of Appeals, Eighth Circuit. Submitted Sept. 11, 2001. Filed Oct. 10, 2001.

*590Before BOWMAN, HEANEY, and BYE, Circuit Judges.

PER CURIAM.

Randy MeClean, a manufactured-home dealer, was charged with three counts of wire fraud. See 18 U.S.C. § 1343 (1994). A jury convicted MeClean of two of the counts and the District Court1 sentenced MeClean to serve concurrent twenty-seven month sentences, to make restitution, and to pay a special assessment. On appeal, MeClean raises issues regarding the sufficiency of the evidence, the determination of loss, and his sentence. Having reviewed the record and the arguments of both parties, we reject McClean’s arguments and affirm the District Court.

MeClean argues that the government did not introduce sufficient evidence of his intent to commit wire fraud. When addressing a sufficiency-of-the-evidence claim, we review the evidence in the light most favorable to the verdict and reverse only if no reasonable jury could have found the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. United States v. Rounsavall, 115 F.3d 561, 565 (8th Cir.), cert, denied, 522 U.S. 903, 118 S.Ct. 256, 139 L.Ed.2d 183 (1997). The government’s evidence showed that MeClean admitted that he deceived interested business associates with false statements made by telephone and facsimile and that MeClean knew that he put these associates at financial risk. Although MeClean stated that he intended to repay the parties in his business transactions who suffered losses and that he intended no harm, the jury was free to disbelieve him. See United States v. Ervasti 201 F.3d 1029, 1037 (8th Cir.2000). We hold the evidence was sufficient for a reasonable jury to find guilt.

With regard to his sentence, MeClean argues that the District Court erred in determining the amount of the monetary loss he caused. We review the District Court’s interpretation and application of the sentencing guidelines de novo and the District Court’s factual findings for clear error. United States v. Oligmueller, 198 F.3d 669, 671 (8th Cir.1999). The District Court calculated the loss caused by MeClean by examining the losses incurred by two victims of his fraud — a building supply company (Wick Building Systems) and a bank (Green Tree Financial Corporation). These losses included *591unpaid loan guaranties and unpaid reimbursement for home sales. Sentencing McClean in accordance with U.S.S.G. § 2F1.1, the District Court found — relying on the presentence investigation report and evidence at the sentencing hearing— that the amount of loss was in the range of $500,000 to $800,000. The District Court’s finding is supported by the record and is not clearly erroneous.

Finally, McClean argues that his twenty-seven month sentence violates the Supreme Court’s decision in Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466, 120 S.Ct. 2348, 147 L.Ed.2d 435 (2000). We note that Apprendi dealt with a non-jury factual determination that was used as a basis for a sentence in excess of the statutory maximum sentence. Id. at 491-95, 120 S.Ct. 2348. Because McClean’s sentence was less than the statutory maximum for wire fraud (five years), Apprendi does not apply. See United States v. Aguayo-Delgado, 220 F.3d 926, 933-34 (8th Cir.), cert, denied, 531 U.S. 1026, 121 S.Ct. 600, 148 L.Ed.2d 513 (2000).2

Accordingly, we affirm.

. The Honorable Michael J. Melloy, United States District Judge for the Northern District of Iowa.

. We note that the Appellee cited an unpublished opinion in its brief. The citation was appropriate when it was offered, because at that time Anastasoff, which proved to be short-lived, was the law of the Circuit. See Anastasoff v. United States, 223 F.3d 898 (8th Cir.), vacated as moot, Anastasoff v. United States, 235 F.3d 1054 (8th Cir.2000) (en banc). We note the Rules of the Eighth Circuit currently bar the citation of unpublished opinions. See 8th Cir. R. 28A(i).
